Students may have difficulty understanding the concept of armed conflict over religious differences. If needed, read aloud the handout in Step 2 to students, guiding them to recognize the main idea of the interrelated nature of language and religion in many places.

Students may incorrectly think that plants do cellular respiration at night only. Encourage them to think about why we were unable to observe plants releasing CO2 during our plants in the light investigation.

Students may need an introduction to grid modernization before you begin this activity. Use the "Toilets and the SMART GRID" video clip from the film Earth: The Operator's Manual to introduce the concept.
Students may work in groups of three or four if you are short on molecule kits for the optional modeling step.
Students may work in groups of three or four if you are short on molecule kits.
Students may work in groups of three or four if you are short on molecule kits.

Sunspot graph data will fluctuate depending on the solar activity of the day. The calculations for the chart should leave students with an average rotational period of between 25 and 36 days. You may want to check the current solar activity before you set up the activity. If there isn't enough for students to track, select a date range on the SOHO website that will provide enough sunspot activity for them to track.
Take some time to play with Lapse It or other time-lapse photography apps, as well as uploading and projecting the videos, to ensure this part of the activity goes smoothly.
Take some time to play with the Lapse It or other time-lapse photography apps, as well as uploading and projecting the videos, to ensure this part of the activity goes smoothly.
Teacher Tip: Give students a chance to express their own ideas. You will have the opportunity to revisit these ideas later in the unit.

Teacher Tip: The space under a grow light may be limited. You may consider doing a small number of plants per class period using larger groups. You may be able to create more lighted space under the grow light using aluminum foil.
Teacher Tip: You may want to post the Three Questions Poster in a prominent place in your classroom. The questions on the poster will be revisited often throughout the unit.
Teachers might consider having students conduct and present their nanotechnology research using a jigsaw approach.
The case studies can be presented orally or in writing.
The checklist includes instructions on where and how to record data.

The grow light has space for approximately 24 aluminum cups. This means you may have a total of 24 groups per investigation but no more. If you have multiple classes doing the investigation at the same time, you may need to make larger groups so that you have no more than 24 cups of plants growing at one time.

 When you input data into Plants Class Results Spreadsheet, the spreadsheet will automatically create charts of the data you can use to help students interpret the results.

The numbers for supplies are approximate, based on a five-cycle simulation using all four cities. Increase or decrease the number of payment tokens and chips to change the number of cycles or to include more or fewer cities.
The save cards have a "double meaning." They are to be saved to play later in the game and they are also the cards that save the pups from a predator.

The space under a fluorescent lamp may be limited. You may consider doing a small number of plants per class period using larger groups. You may be able to create more lighted space under the grow light using aluminum foil.
The tips for choosing a topic in step 5 are based on the three understandings of geo-literacy. For more information on geo-literacy, see the For Further Exploration section.

The transparency of each layer on the MapMaker Interactive can be adjusted if students are having trouble seeing map features and overlapping layers. To adjust, move the cursor along the Transparency scale that is located underneath each Layer title in the Themes box.

This activity can be conducted over multiple class periods. Complete steps 1–5 in one class period and conduct the testing over a second class period. If needed, students can complete the final evaluation step during a third session or as homework.
This activity can be used as a long-term project if your class pursues the opportunity to change the land use of a vacant lot.

This activity contains content-area reading and listening. Support students who have difficulty comprehending some of the text by providing scaffolding such as reinforcing vocabulary concepts, using words in context, predicting, summarizing and clarifying key points, and modeling comprehension strategies.
This activity is designed as an outdoor activity. To adapt it for inside, ask students to observe and record objects rather than wildlife specimens.

This activity simplifies the full story of what happens during the multi-step process of photosynthesis. For a more detailed account, see http://dqc.crcstl.msu.edu/node/2027. 

 a standard but simplified formula for the overall chemical change:
          6 CO2 + 6 H2OàC6H12O6 + 6 O2

This activity uses photographs from different countries and regions of Europe. You may choose to use photographs from one country or one region. If so, use provided worksheet Make Observations: One Country or Region.
This activity will take 45 minutes with optional activities.
This activity would be ideal for a science center, perhaps used during "free choice" time.

This incorrectly suggests that some of the oxygen atoms in CO2 end up in O2, which is not actually the case.  A more accurate formula to represent the multi-step process would be as follows:
         C6H12O6 + 6 O2 + 6 H2O à 6 CO2 + 12 H2O
Thus all of the oxygen atoms in O2 (bolded in the equation above) come from H2O, while the oxygen atoms in CO2 all go to glucose or water.
This investigation is safe in the hands of students. Conduct it as a demonstration if there are not enough materials for every student group to do their own investigation.
This investigation may not be necessary for more advanced students.
This investigation may not be necessary for more advanced students.
This lesson should be done in 10 minutes in two class periods each, with time in between to allow the carrot and sponge to dry.
To accommodate visual learners, print images of the various models in step 6 or allow students to search for them online.
To increase student accountability in Step 3, assign each group the research questions before they start their research and have each group share their answers with the class.
To increase the difficulty of the activity, use the Israel MapMaker 1-Page Map to adjust the map so that place names are not included on the map. Ask students to label the map themselves.

To lessen the game's win/lose aspects with younger groups, monitor the play. Reward "bonus" pups when needed. For example, if a student is losing all pups, say "Your pups are having a very rainy season with lots of rain. You get a bonus pup!"

To make this activity more hands-on, and to help your kinesthetic learners, obtain examples of the actual instruments from the school science lab or other teachers. Allow students to touch and examine them.
To save classroom time, the mealworms could be separated from the meal bedding using a colander before the investigation starts.
To shorten this activity to one hour, work with the art teacher ahead of time. Have students create their pictures in art class first. Then display them in your classroom.

To show an ecosystem in balance, periodically take sharks out of the simulation and make sure students understand that they represent sharks that leave an ecosystem because they die. Bring those students back into the simulation as newly born turtles or dugongs.
To support visual and auditory learners, watch a video version of an ABC News report titled “Solar power plan under fire in Panoche Valley.”

Try the activity ahead of time to test how different shapes of cubes and sculptures and the ambient temperature in your classroom affect the melting rate, as these elements are different in different settings. This information will help you determine the capture and playback rates on the Frame It app.
Use molecular model kits to have students make molecules that exist in air.
Use molecular models for this activity if your students had difficulty developing a full account of cellular respiration.
Use molecular models for this activity if your students had difficulty developing a full account of cellular respiration.
Use molecular models for this activity if your students had difficulty developing a full account of ethanol burning. Some students will be able to answer the Three Questions without making models.
Use molecular models for this activity if your students had difficulty developing a full account of ethanol burning.
Use molecular models for this activity if your students had difficulty developing a full account of ethanol burning.
Use other accounts of research in the news to tie this topic to current events.
Use the Impact of Seafood interactive to research locally fished species.
Use the questions and answers in Part C of the worksheet to guide a whole class discussion instead of having students work individually.
Use this optional activity for students who are less experienced with systems at different scales.
Watch the Santa Monica Bioblitz video before going outside. How many species can you spot during the video?

When showing the robotic arm video (start at minute 1:25) on WebEcoist, note that care should be taken not to show the image above the video, since it gives away the answer. Show two other designs from this page, taking care not to display the titles.
When students are coming up with their stories about the whales, encourage them to be creative. There is no right or wrong answer as to why the whales went where they did.
When you input data into Plants Class Results Spreadsheet, the spreadsheet will automatically create charts of the data you can use to help students interpret the results.
While playing take-away, refer back to the image of the three meerkats, where their physical adaptations are visible.
While we do not recommend this, Parts 1 and 2 of the Carbon TIME Plants Video show the investigation and patterns of results. Students can watch the video instead of doing the investigation.
While we do not recommend this, Parts 1 and 2 of the Carbon TIME Plants Video show the investigation and patterns of results. Students can watch the video instead of doing the investigation.
Write Dr. Earle's quote on a poster board and display it in the classroom a couple of days before ocean instruction begins.
Write important vocabulary words on the board to help English language learners absorb the information.
You can adapt the activity for different MapMaker Kit sizes as needed for different settings.

You can also have students do this activity in small groups. For each group, print one copy of each worksheet on card stock and cut out the cards. One at a time, project and scroll through the two photo galleries, providing groups with enough time to read aloud cards and identify descriptive clues before matching descriptions to photos.
You can also use this activity in English Language Arts classes to focus on word origin, word families, spelling, and related vocabulary skills.
You can provide magazines, glue, and any other art supplies to the students for use during their brainstorm on the map panel.
You can simplify the activity by assigning students a dive location instead of having them research to find one.

You can teach students to “Leave No Trace” when they explore or experience a natural environment. One of the seven LNT principles states “Leave rocks, plants and other natural objects as you find them.” Have students make sure they leave no evidence of their bioblitz by returning to their original place any objects moved or changed by their study.
You can use Lesson 10 as a summative assessment for the full unit.
You may choose to conduct the demonstration with more items (i.e., a head of lettuce, a wet paper towel, etc.) or less items (only the carrot).

You may choose to modify the activity as needed based on time constraints, group sizes, and student background knowledge. For example, the organisms and ecosystems used can be based on those provided in Lesson 2: Marine Ecosystems and Biodiversity.
You may find it helpful to give students copies of the Three Questions as they complete this activity.
You may find it valuable to revisit the Powers of Ten poster from Systems & Scale as you do this activity.
You may want to display the results from the Plants in the Dark Investigation from Lesson 2.

You may want to start the activity by first making a connection to your own country’s borders. For example, show a map of the United States and discuss why borders in the United States are located where they are, including both physical and cultural reasons.
You might find it helpful to have students revisit the Three Questions 11 x 17 Poster on the wall and check their responses. Do all of their responses follow the rules? Don't forget: Atoms endure!
You might find it helpful to have students revisit the Three Questions poster on the wall and check their responses. Do all of their responses follow the rules? Don't forget: Atoms endure!
You might want to post the Lesson 3.2 Class Results for Mealworm Investigation 11 x 17 Poster in a prominent place in the classroom so students can refer to class results during this lesson.
You might want to post the Lesson 3.2 Class Results in a prominent place in the classroom so students can refer to class results during this lesson.
[When video is ready.] As a backup, have students watch the video of ethanol burning.
• English Language Learners tip: Pre-teach the terms pupil, eyeball, and retina. This will help them identify words, place them in context, and remember them.
